text: India is the 7th largest country in the world by land area.
It has a coastline of over 7,500 kilometers.
The country is bordered by Pakistan, China, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, and Myanmar.
The highest point in India is Kangchenjunga, the world's third highest mountain at 8,586 meters.

text: The Thar Desert, also known as the Great Indian Desert, is located in the northwestern part of the country.
India has two major island groups: the Lakshadweep Islands off the west coast and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands off the east coast.
The Ganges (Ganga) is the most sacred river to Hindus and is also one of the most polluted rivers in the world.
India experiences six primary seasons: spring, summer, monsoon, autumn, pre-winter, and winter, according to the Hindu calendar.
The Sundarbans, in the Ganges Delta, is the largest mangrove forest in the world and home to the Royal Bengal Tiger.
India's southern tip, Kanyakumari, is where the Arabian Sea, the Bay of Bengal, and the Indian Ocean meet.
The Indus Valley Civilization, one of the world's oldest, flourished around 2500 BCE in what is now Pakistan and western India.
The Maurya Empire, founded by Chandragupta Maurya in 322 BCE, was one of the largest empires in the world at its time.
Emperor Ashoka, a Mauryan ruler, renounced violence after the bloody Kalinga War and embraced Buddhism.
The Mughal Empire ruled India from the early 16th to the mid-18th century, leaving a rich architectural legacy like the Taj Mahal.
The Taj Mahal in Agra was built by Emperor Shah Jahan as a mausoleum for his favorite wife, Mumtaz Mahal.
The British East India Company established trading posts in India in the early 1600s, eventually leading to British colonial rule.
The Indian Rebellion of 1857 was a major, but ultimately unsuccessful, uprising against British rule.
Mahatma Gandhi led the non-violent resistance movement against British colonial rule, advocating for Swaraj (self-rule).
India gained independence from British rule on August 15, 1947.
The partition of India in 1947 also created the new nation of Pakistan, leading to one of the largest mass migrations in history.
India is the birthplace of four major world religions: Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, and Sikhism.
The traditional greeting in India is Namaste, often accompanied by a slight bow with palms pressed together.
Indian cuisine is known for its sophisticated use of spices and herbs, varying greatly by region.
Bollywood, based in Mumbai, is the largest film industry in the world by number of films produced.
Yoga, a group of physical, mental, and spiritual practices, originated in ancient India.
The sari is a traditional garment worn by millions of Indian women.
Diwali, the festival of lights, is one of the most important Hindu festivals.
Holi, the festival of colors, marks the arrival of spring and is celebrated by throwing colored powder and water.
Classical Indian dance forms include Bharatanatyam, Kathak, Odissi, and Kathakali.
The national animal of India is the Bengal Tiger.
The national bird of India is the Indian Peafowl, or Peacock.
The national flower of India is the Lotus.
The national fruit of India is the Mango.
Cricket is the most popular sport in India, almost a religion for many.
Field Hockey is the national sport of India.
Chess is believed to have originated in India, where it was known as Chaturanga.
The game of Snakes and Ladders was invented in India as a moral lesson about karma.
The Kumbh Mela, a massive Hindu pilgrimage, is the largest gathering of people on Earth.
Ayurveda is a traditional system of medicine with historical roots in the Indian subcontinent.
India has 22 officially recognized languages, with Hindi and English being the official government languages.
India is the world's fifth-largest economy by nominal GDP.
It is the third-largest economy by purchasing power parity (PPP).
India is one of the world's largest exporters of software services and IT workforce.
The country is a major producer of textiles, pharmaceuticals, and automotive parts.
Agriculture employs about half of India's workforce.
India is the world's largest producer of milk, pulses, and jute.
It is the second-largest producer of wheat, rice, sugarcane, cotton, and groundnuts.
The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) is one of the world's leading space agencies, known for its cost-effective missions.
Mumbai is the financial, commercial, and entertainment capital of India.
Bengaluru is known as the Silicon Valley of India for its numerous IT companies.
India is the world's largest democracy.
It has a parliamentary system of government based on the British model.
The Constitution of India is the longest written constitution of any sovereign country in the world.
India is a federal union comprising 28 states and 8 union territories.
New Delhi is the capital of India.
The President of India is the head of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government.
Elections in India are the largest democratic exercise in the world, with hundreds of millions of voters.
The Indian Parliament is bicameral, consisting of the Lok Sabha (House of the People) and the Rajya Sabha (Council of States).
India is a founding member of the Non-Aligned Movement and the United Nations.
India has nuclear weapons and is considered a nuclear-weapon state.
The number zero and the decimal system are considered Indian inventions.
Ancient Indian mathematicians Aryabhata and Brahmagupta made significant contributions to algebra and astronomy.
ISRO's Mars Orbiter Mission (Mangalyaan) was the world's least expensive Mars mission to reach the planet's orbit.
India has one of the largest pools of scientists and engineers in the world.
The Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) are world-renowned premier institutes for engineering education.
The Indian Institutes of Management (IIMs) are among Asia's top business schools.
India has a rapidly growing startup ecosystem, with numerous unicorns (startups valued over $1 billion).
The country has a strong pharmaceutical industry, often called the pharmacy of the world for its generic drug production.
India's Chandrayaan-3 mission successfully landed a rover on the moon's south pole in 2023.
The world's first university, Takshashila, was established in India around 700 BCE.
India is home to over 70% of the world's wild tiger population.
It is the only country in the world where both lions and tigers are found.
The Asiatic Lion's only natural habitat is the Gir Forest in Gujarat.
India has over 500 wildlife sanctuaries and more than 100 national parks.
The Indian Elephant is a recognized subspecies of the Asian elephant and is the national heritage animal.
The one-horned Indian Rhinoceros is found in the northeastern state of Assam.
India is a major destination for birdwatchers, with over 1300 species of birds.
The King Cobra, the world's longest venomous snake, is native to India.
The Western Ghats mountain range is one of the world's eight hottest hotspots of biological diversity.
Project Tiger, launched in 1973, is a major wildlife conservation initiative in India.
Chai (tea) is the most popular beverage in India, consumed throughout the day.
Indian food varies widely: North Indian cuisine features breads like naan and curries, while South Indian cuisine is known for its rice-based dishes like dosa and idli.
The world's hottest chili pepper, the Bhut Jolokia (Ghost Pepper), is from India.
Panipuri (or Golgappa) is a popular street food consisting of a hollow puri filled with spicy flavored water, tamarind chutney, and potatoes.
India is the world's largest consumer of vegetarian food.
Biryani, a spiced rice and meat dish, is a culinary gift from the Mughals and is immensely popular.
Butter Chicken and Chicken Tikka Masala are famous Punjabi dishes popular worldwide.
The staple food for most of South India is rice, while in the North it is wheat.
Masala Dosa, a crispy crepe filled with spiced potatoes, is a classic breakfast dish from South India.
India produces over a hundred varieties of mangoes, each with a unique taste and texture.
The Taj Mahal is one of the Seven Wonders of the Modern World.
Khajuraho Temples are famous for their nagara-style architectural symbolism and erotic sculptures.
The Konark Sun Temple in Odisha is shaped like a gigantic chariot with elaborately carved stone wheels, walls, and pillars.
The Ellora Caves are a magnificent complex of rock-cut monasteries and temples representing Buddhism, Hinduism, and Jainism.
The Hawa Mahal, or Palace of Winds, in Jaipur is a five-story pyramidal monument with 953 small windows.
The Victoria Terminus (now Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus) in Mumbai is a stunning example of Victorian Gothic Revival architecture.
The Meenakshi Amman Temple in Madurai is famed for its towering gopurams (gateway towers) covered in thousands of colorful sculptures.
The stepwells of Gujarat and Rajasthan, like Rani ki Vav, are intricate subterranean water storage systems and architectural marvels.
The Lotus Temple in Delhi, a Baháʼí House of Worship, is renowned for its flowerlike shape and is built from white marble.
Ancient Indian architecture includes the detailed science of Vastu Shastra, which focuses on design, layout, and spatial geometry.
Diwali: The five-day Festival of Lights celebrates the victory of light over darkness and good over evil.
Holi: The Festival of Colors involves throwing colored powders and water at each other in a joyful celebration.
Dussehra: Celebrates the victory of Lord Rama over the demon king Ravana, often involving the burning of large effigies.
Navratri & Durga Puja: A nine-night festival worshipping the goddess Durga, celebrated with dance (Garba) and elaborate pandals (temporary structures).
Ganesh Chaturthi: A 10-day festival celebrating the birth of the elephant-headed god, Lord Ganesha, ending with the immersion of idols in water.
Onam: A major harvest festival in Kerala, featuring snake boat races, elaborate flower carpets (Pookalam), and a grand feast (Onam Sadya).
Pongal/Makar Sankranti: A multi-day harvest festival in South India, thanking the Sun God and nature.
Eid-ul-Fitr and Eid-ul-Adha: Major Islamic festivals celebrated with prayers, feasts, and charity.
Christmas: Celebrated by Christians across India, with Goa and Kerala having significant celebrations.
Vaisakhi: A harvest festival in Punjab that also marks the Sikh New Year and the formation of the Khalsa Panth.
Hindi is the most widely spoken language in India, but it is not the mother tongue of the majority.
The Constitution of India recognizes 22 scheduled languages.
English is widely used for official, business, and administrative purposes.
Tamil, spoken in Tamil Nadu, is one of the world's oldest living languages.
Sanskrit is the primary liturgical language of Hinduism and the origin of many Indian languages.
India has hundreds of active dialects in addition to its major languages.
The Devanagari script is used for Hindi, Sanskrit, and Marathi.
India has no national language; Hindi and English are official languages of the Union government.
Each state of India has its own official language(s).
Indian languages belong to several language families, the largest being Indo-Aryan and Dravidian.
The Indian Railways is one of the world's largest railway networks, employing over a million people.
Mumbai's local train network is one of the busiest in the world, carrying millions of passengers daily.
The Auto Rickshaw (tuk-tuk) is a ubiquitous three-wheeled vehicle for hire in Indian cities.
The Howrah Bridge in Kolkata is a famous cantilever bridge and a symbol of the city.
The Delhi Metro is one of the largest and most modern metro rail systems in the world.
India's national highway network is the second-longest in the world.
The 'Jugaad' is a makeshift vehicle, often homemade, used in rural India for transport.
The Bandra-Worli Sea Link in Mumbai is a cable-stayed bridge that is an engineering marvel.
Varanasi's river ghats, with countless boats, are a unique form of water-based transport and ritual space.
The Darjeeling Himalayan Railway, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is a famous narrow-gauge mountain railway.
Indian classical music has two major traditions: Hindustani (North Indian) and Carnatic (South Indian).
The sitar, tabla, and veena are famous Indian musical instruments.
Ravi Shankar, a sitar virtuoso, popularized Indian classical music in the West.
Rangoli is a folk art where patterns are created on the floor using materials like colored rice, flour, or flowers.
Madhubani painting, from Bihar, is a style characterized by eye-catching geometrical patterns.
The ancient text Natya Shastra is a foundational treatise on the performing arts, including dance and music.
Rabindranath Tagore was the first non-European to win the Nobel Prize in Literature (1913).
Indian cinema includes not just Bollywood (Hindi) but also prolific industries like Tollywood (Telugu) and Kollywood (Tamil).
Mehndi is the application of henna as a temporary form of skin decoration, especially for weddings.
Kalarippayattu, from Kerala, is one of the oldest surviving martial arts in the world.
India is the world's second-most populous country, with over 1.4 billion people.
The country has a very young population, with a median age of around 28 years.
The joint family system, where multiple generations live together, is a traditional social unit.
Arranged marriages are still a common practice in many parts of India.
Indian weddings are often large, multi-day affairs with elaborate rituals and ceremonies.
The caste system, though officially outlawed, continues to influence social dynamics.
India has a vast and growing diaspora, with over 30 million people of Indian origin living abroad.
The concept of 'Atithi Devo Bhava' (The guest is God) is a core tenet of Indian hospitality.
India is one of the most religiously diverse nations in the world, with major religions coexisting.
The sacred cow: Cows are venerated in Hinduism and have a special status in Indian society and law.
The world's highest cricket ground is in Chail, Himachal Pradesh, India.
India has the largest number of vegetarians in the world.
The first rocket in India was transported on a bicycle and the first satellite on a bullock cart.
The number system and the concept of zero were invented in India.
India has the world's largest postal network, with over 150,000 post offices.
Varanasi is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world.
The game of Ludo originated in India as Pachisi.
India's national calendar is based on the Saka era, with Chaitra as its first month.
The magnetic hill in Ladakh is an optical illusion that makes cars appear to roll uphill.
India is the only country to have a Bill of Rights for animals.
The world's largest family lives in India: a man with 39 wives and 94 children.
India has the lowest divorce rate in the world, at around 1%.
The Himalayas, meaning abode of snow, form a natural barrier between the Indian subcontinent and the Tibetan plateau.
India has over 300,000 mosques, more than any other country in the world, including the Muslim world.
The first country to grow sugar was India.
The Bengal Famine of 1943 was a major famine during World War II that killed an estimated 2-3 million people.
The Bhopal Gas Tragedy in 1984 was one of the world's worst industrial disasters.
The Indian peacekeeping force was a major contributor to UN peacekeeping missions for decades.
The Indian Plate is still moving northward, causing the Himalayas to rise slightly each year.
The world's first university was established in Takshashila in 700BC.
Algebra, Trigonometry and Calculus originated in India.
The value of pi was first calculated by the Indian mathematician Budhayana.
India has the world's third-largest active army.
The Indian Navy's INS Vikramaditya is one of the largest aircraft carriers in the world.
The Bangalore Palace was built in 1887 and is inspired by England's Windsor Castle.
India has the largest English-speaking population in the world after the United States.
The world's largest religious building, Angkor Wat, is a Hindu temple complex located in Cambodia.
The first time the world saw a tiger census was in India in 1932.
India has the world's largest movie studio, Ramoji Film City in Hyderabad.
The Indian flag was designed by Pingali Venkayya and was adopted in its present form in 1947.
The saffron color in the flag stands for courage and sacrifice, white for peace and truth, and green for faith and chivalry.
The Ashoka Chakra in the center of the flag has 24 spokes.
The national anthem, Jana Gana Mana, was composed by Rabindranath Tagore.
The national song, Vande Mataram, was composed by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee.
The Indian Rupee sign (₹) was adopted in 2010, designed by D. Udaya Kumar.
India has the world's largest road network, after the United States.
The world's highest motorable road is in India, Umling La Pass in Ladakh at 19,300 feet.
The Chenab Bridge is the world's highest railway bridge, taller than the Eiffel Tower.
The Statue of Unity, a statue of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, is the world's tallest statue at 182 meters.
Shampoo was invented in India, using herbs and extracts.
India is the world's largest democracy by electorate size.
The world's largest monsoon season occurs in India.
The Indian Ocean is named after India.
India has the world's largest population of wild Asiatic elephants.
The world's largest sundial is in Jaipur, India.
India has the world's largest film industry by number of films produced annually.
The world's largest family lives in India: a man with 39 wives and 94 children.
India has the world's largest school by number of students, City Montessori School in Lucknow.
The world's largest producer of films is India, not Hollywood.
India is the world's largest milk producer, thanks to Operation Flood, the world's largest dairy development program.
